topics.title: People, Places and Objects to Respect
topics.description: Meaning of respect; people, places and things to respect (traditional rulers, parents, leaders, national symbols, public properties, time).
objectives: Define respect
Identify people, places and things to respect
Demonstrate ways of respecting people, places and things
activities: Teacher tells stories about why elders and leaders should be respected
Teacher demonstrates ways to show respect in local contexts
Show charts and pictures (mosque, church, palace, flag, mace, constitution)
resources: Charts and pictures of mosque, church, palace, national flag, mace, constitution
Visits to important places (palace, mosque, church, museum, National Assembly)
evaluation: Pupils define respect
Pupils name places or objects that should be respected
Pupils state two reasons for respecting elders/teachers/leaders
Pupils demonstrate ways to show respect

topics.title: Rules and Regulations in the Society
topics.description: Rules and regulations are do's and don'ts that guide social behaviour; includes NAFDAC rules on food and drug control.
objectives: Explain the meaning of rules and regulations
Mention gains of obeying rules and regulations
Mention results of disobeying rules and regulations
Mention rules/regulations for food and drug administration
activities: Class discussion on meaning of rules and regulations
Show pictures/video clips of children receiving gifts to discuss gains of obedience
Present pictures of children suffering consequences of disobedience
Discuss NAFDAC laws and regulations on food and drugs
resources: Textbooks, pictures of children receiving gifts, video clips
Food and drug packs and instructional leaflets, diagrams of foods and drugs
evaluation: Pupils say what to do and not to do in community
Pupils mention gains of obeying rules
Pupils mention results of disobeying rules
Pupils name three NAFDAC rules on foods and drugs control

topics.title: Importance of Civic Education
topics.description: Why study Civic Education: understand democratic and civic rights and responsibilities, nurture democracy; includes public health campaigns (HIV/AIDS, drug abuse).
objectives: Discuss the need for Civic Education in Nigeria
Mention topics learnt in Civic Education and their importance
Identify some public health enlightenment campaigns
activities: Guided discussion on need for Civic Education
Lead pupils to name topics and benefits of Civic Education
Guide class to identify public health campaigns and their roles
resources: Textbooks, pictures/video clips of democratic activities, radio jingles, posters
evaluation: Pupils say why Civic Education is important
Pupils enumerate three benefits from studying Civic Education
Pupils mention two public health awareness campaigns

topics.title: Meaning of Social Studies
topics.description: Social Studies is the study of man and how his problems are solved in the environment.
objectives: Explain the meaning of Social Studies
activities: Teacher explains and guides pupils to explain the meaning of Social Studies
Class Q&A
evaluation: Pupil explains the meaning of Social Studies

topics.title: The Family (Types and Responsibilities)
topics.description: The family is the basic unit of society. Types include nuclear and extended; family members have roles and responsibilities.
objectives: Define family
Identify types of family
Explain roles of family members
activities: Guided questions to discover the meaning of family
Discussion to identify types of family
Ask pupils to find out family information from home
resources: Charts showing nuclear and extended families, family photographs, cartoons, video ROMs
evaluation: Pupils explain meaning of family
Pupils mention two types of family
Pupils explain types of family

topics.title: Qualities of a Good Family
topics.description: Qualities include honesty, contentment, interest for others, not greedy, discipline, obedience, love and cooperation.
objectives: State qualities of a good family
activities: Guide pupils to identify and explain qualities of a good family
Role-play family behaviours demonstrating honesty, love and obedience
resources: Pictures and charts showing moral values
evaluation: Pupils mention three qualities of a good family

topics.title: Meaning and Types of Culture
topics.description: Culture is people's ways of life (dressing, dancing, eating); types include material and non-material culture.
objectives: Explain the meaning of culture
List types of culture
activities: Guided questions and role play to explain culture
Identify material and non-material culture with examples
resources: Pictures of traditional dress, cultural objects, charts
evaluation: Pupils state meaning of culture and explain types of culture

topics.title: Values that Show Good Morals
topics.description: Moral values considered right (greeting, respect, loyalty, kindness, honesty, contentment, tolerance) and wrong values (stealing, bullying, fighting, lying).
objectives: Explain values which show good morals
Differentiate between right and wrong values
activities: Lead discussion on moral values
Demonstrate examples of good and bad values using role play
resources: Cartoons, posters, ROM films, photographs, exhibits
evaluation: Pupils explain values considered right and wrong

topics.title: Food (meaning, local foods and sources)
topics.description: Definition of food, common local foods, and sources of food in the community (farms, markets, rivers).
objectives: Define food
Mention foods eaten in the locality
Mention sources of food in the community
activities: Ask pupils to bring food samples from home and identify them
Class discussion and painting of food items
resources: Real food items, pictures of foods, video clips, pictures of farms and markets
evaluation: Pupils define food
Pupils list five foods eaten locally
Pupils state sources of food in the community

topics.title: Food Safety
topics.description: How to ensure that what we eat, drink or take is not harmful to health; includes reading labels, observing signs of spoilage, and washing hands.
objectives: Define food safety
Mention ways of ensuring food safety
activities: Lead pupils to define food safety
Ask questions to identify ways of making food safe (wash hands, check labels, observe spoilage signs)
resources: Pupils' textbooks, pictures showing ways of making food safe
evaluation: Pupils define food safety
Pupils mention ways of ensuring food safety

topics.title: Risk Factors in Food
topics.description: Risk factors that drive occurrence of hazards in food: adulteration, food fraud, agro-chemical contamination; risks in distribution/preparation include poor storage, poor handling and poor hygiene.
objectives: Explain meaning of risk factors
State risk factors in food
Identify risk factors in food distribution and preparation
activities: Present pictures of risk factors in food distribution and preparation
Guide pupils to state risk factors and discuss poor storage/handling
resources: Pupils' textbooks, video clips on risk factors, pictures/photographs
evaluation: Pupils explain risk factors
Pupils list risk factors in food and distribution

topics.title: Sources and Uses of Water
topics.description: Sources of water (stream, spring, river, tap, borehole, rainfall, well) and domestic uses (drinking, washing, cooking).
objectives: Mention sources of water supply in the locality
Enumerate uses of water in homes
activities: Lead discussion and use pictures to guide pupils in enumerating sources and uses
Interpret pictures of water sources
resources: Pictures depicting sources of water, pictures showing domestic water uses
evaluation: Pupils name four sources of water
Pupils list three uses of water

topics.title: Concept of Security
topics.description: Security of life and property: meaning, sources of danger (road accidents, fire outbreaks, strangers, unsafe food, fake drugs) and precautions.
objectives: Explain the meaning of security
Take precautions against dangers
activities: Guide pupils to explain security and identify sources of danger
Role-play fire outbreaks/road accidents and appropriate responses
resources: Textbooks, pictures on road accidents and fire outbreaks
evaluation: Pupils explain meaning of security
Pupils give examples of sources of insecurity and precautionary measures

topics.title: Reasons for Taking Substances into the Body
topics.description: Reasons for taking substances: stay alive, hunger, thirst, enjoyment, imitation, curiosity, availability; effects include stomach pain, vomiting, restlessness, dizziness, fainting, death.
objectives: Give reasons for taking substances into the body
Mention effects of taking substances into the body
activities: Call on pupils to demonstrate reasons
Dramatize reasons and use stories to highlight effects
Ask pupils to narrate experiences
evaluation: Pupils give reasons for taking substances
Pupils mention four effects of taking substances

topics.title: Overdose (too much eating, drinking or smoking)
topics.description: Causes and observable signs/symptoms of overdose (coughing, fainting, stooling); effects of too much eating/drinking/inhaling and what to do to help sufferers (report to adults, seek help).
objectives: Demonstrate looks and behaviours of people who take too much
Mention effects of drinking too much
Mention effects of inhaling too much
Say what to do to help somebody suffering overdose
activities: Present drawings/paintings to show effects
Ask pupils to narrate experiences and dramatize suggestions
Guide a play or drama on the topic
resources: Charts, pictures, posters, drawing materials, posters of children helping sufferers
evaluation: Pupils mention effects of drinking too much
Pupils mention three effects of inhaling too much
Pupils demonstrate behaviours and looks of people who overeat/drink/smoke
Pupils state actions to help overdose sufferers (report to adults, seek help)
